expanded_description: Newton's First Law of Motion, also called the Law of Inertia, describes what happens when no net force acts on an object. It fundamentally changes our understanding of motion by establishing that forces cause changes in motion, not motion itself.

core_concept.principle: Newton's First Law states: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with constant velocity (same speed and direction), unless acted upon by a net external force. This law defines inertia—the tendency of objects to resist changes in their motion.
core_concept.explanation: Before Newton, people believed that force was required to maintain motion—that objects naturally slow down and stop without continuous pushing. Aristotle's view seemed correct from everyday experience: push a book across a table and it stops when you stop pushing. Newton's insight was revolutionary: objects don't naturally stop—friction stops them. Without friction (imagine ice or space), objects continue moving at constant velocity forever without any force. This is inertia. The First Law has two parts: (1) Objects at rest remain at rest unless a net force acts. A book on a table stays put until pushed. (2) Objects in motion continue at constant velocity (same speed and direction) unless a net force acts. A hockey puck sliding on ice continues at nearly constant velocity because friction is very small. The key phrase is 'net force'—if all forces balance (net force = zero), the object maintains its current state: rest stays rest, constant velocity motion continues unchanged. Only unbalanced forces (net force ≠ zero) cause acceleration. Understanding the First Law is crucial because it establishes the concept of inertial reference frames, explains why we need seat belts (our bodies want to continue at constant velocity when car suddenly stops), and forms the foundation for Newton's other laws.

sections.introduction: Newton's First Law introduces the concept of inertia—the property of matter that resists changes in motion.

key_concept.definition: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion. Objects at rest resist being set in motion. Objects in motion resist changes in velocity (speed or direction). Mass is the measure of inertia—more massive objects have greater inertia and are harder to accelerate or decelerate.
key_concept.context: Inertia is a fundamental property of all matter. You experience inertia daily: difficulty starting a heavy object moving, difficulty stopping a moving object, being pushed back in your seat when a car accelerates, being thrown forward when a car brakes suddenly.

principles.statement: An object at rest remains at rest, and an object in motion continues moving with constant velocity (constant speed in a straight line), unless acted upon by a net external force.
principles.application: When net force is zero ($\sum \vec{F} = 0$), velocity is constant (which includes $v = 0$ as special case of constant velocity).
principles.example: Book on table: at rest, remains at rest (zero velocity continues). Puck on ice: moving at 5 m/s eastward, continues at 5 m/s eastward (constant velocity continues). Both have zero net force.

principles.statement: Inertia is resistance to acceleration. Objects don't 'want' to accelerate—they prefer to maintain current velocity (including zero).
principles.application: Greater mass → greater inertia → harder to change motion.
principles.example: Easy to push empty shopping cart (low mass, low inertia). Hard to push cart full of groceries (high mass, high inertia). Same force produces less acceleration on more massive object.

principles.statement: Mass is the quantitative measure of inertia. An object's mass (in kg) indicates how much it resists acceleration. More mass = more inertia = harder to accelerate.
principles.application: Comparing inertias: compare masses. 10 kg object has twice the inertia of 5 kg object.
principles.example: 5 kg bowling ball harder to start/stop rolling than 0.15 kg baseball. The bowling ball has greater mass, therefore greater inertia.

principles.statement: First Law applies when net force is zero. This can happen two ways: (1) no forces at all, or (2) forces present but balanced (vector sum equals zero).
principles.example: Object in deep space: no forces → constant velocity (case 1). Book on table: gravity down balanced by normal up → net force zero → at rest (constant velocity of zero) continues (case 2).

principles.statement: Being at rest ($v = 0$) is a special case of constant velocity. The First Law treats 'at rest' and 'moving at constant velocity' as the same: both are states maintained when net force is zero.
principles.application: Don't think of rest and motion as fundamentally different. Both are inertial states.
principles.example: Book on table (rest) and puck sliding on frictionless ice at constant 3 m/s (motion) both obey First Law. Both have zero net force, both maintain their state.

classifications.type: Two Parts of the First Law
classifications.value: Rest and motion are treated symmetrically

examples.process: Part 1: Object at rest stays at rest
examples.explanation: Without net force, stationary objects remain stationary. Ball on ground doesn't spontaneously start rolling. Book on shelf doesn't fall (normal force balances gravity). Parked car doesn't start moving by itself.

examples.process: Part 2: Object in motion stays in motion
examples.explanation: Without net force, moving objects maintain constant velocity. Puck on ice glides at constant speed (minimal friction). Satellite in orbit maintains constant speed (gravity perpendicular to motion). Object in space continues moving forever without slowing.
These aren't separate laws—they're the same principle. Zero net force → velocity doesn't change (whether that velocity is zero or non-zero).

characteristics: Heavier objects fall faster? NO (unrelated to First Law)
classifications.behavior: Understanding what First Law does and doesn't say.

examples.process: Misconception: Force needed to keep moving
examples.explanation: FALSE. Force needed only to change motion (accelerate). Constant velocity requires zero net force. We think force needed because friction opposes motion in everyday situations, but that's friction doing work, not a fundamental requirement.

FALSE. Objects slow down because of friction, air resistance, or other opposing forces. Without these forces, motion continues unchanged. In space (no air resistance), objects continue moving indefinitely.

examples.process: Misconception: First Law only applies without forces
examples.explanation: FALSE. First Law applies when net force is zero. Multiple forces can act as long as they balance. Object on table has forces (gravity, normal) but they balance → net force zero → First Law applies.

worked_examples.title: Identifying First Law Situations
worked_examples.problem: Which scenarios demonstrate Newton's First Law? (a) Book resting on table, (b) Car accelerating from stoplight, (c) Hockey puck sliding on ice at constant velocity, (d) Ball falling straight down.

step_by_step.explanation: At rest (v = 0, constant). Forces: gravity down, normal up. Forces balanced → net force = 0. First Law: object at rest stays at rest. YES, demonstrates First Law.
Velocity changing (accelerating). Acceleration requires net force ≠ 0. NOT constant velocity. NO, does not demonstrate First Law (violates it—acceleration means net force present).

step_by_step.step: (c) Puck on ice at constant velocity
step_by_step.explanation: Moving at constant velocity (e.g., 5 m/s eastward, unchanging). Minimal friction → net force ≈ 0. First Law: moving object continues at constant velocity. YES, demonstrates First Law.
Accelerating downward (velocity increasing). Gravity causes net downward force. NOT constant velocity. NO, does not demonstrate First Law.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) YES (rest maintained, balanced forces), (c) YES (constant velocity maintained, minimal net force). (b) NO (accelerating), (d) NO (accelerating).
worked_examples.concept_applied: First Law applies when net force = 0, resulting in constant velocity (including v = 0). Acceleration indicates net force ≠ 0, violating First Law.

worked_examples.title: Understanding Inertia
worked_examples.problem: Two blocks on frictionless ice: Block A has mass 2 kg, Block B has mass 6 kg. Both are initially at rest. The same force is applied to each for the same time. (a) Which has greater inertia? (b) Which will be harder to accelerate? (c) Which will reach higher final velocity?

step_by_step.explanation: Inertia measured by mass. Block A: 2 kg. Block B: 6 kg. Block B has greater mass → greater inertia.
Greater inertia means greater resistance to acceleration. Block B (more massive) is harder to accelerate. Requires more force to achieve same acceleration, or same force produces less acceleration.

Same force, same time, but different masses. From $F = ma$: $a = F/m$. Block A (smaller m) gets larger a. Larger acceleration for same time → greater velocity change → higher final velocity. Block A reaches higher speed.
Greater mass → greater inertia → harder to accelerate → reaches lower velocity for same applied force. Inertia resists changes in motion.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Block B has greater inertia (6 kg > 2 kg), (b) Block B harder to accelerate (more inertia), (c) Block A reaches higher velocity (less inertia, accelerates more)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Mass measures inertia. Greater mass = greater inertia = greater resistance to acceleration = smaller acceleration for same force.

worked_examples.title: Balanced Forces and First Law
worked_examples.problem: A 5 kg box is pushed to the right with 20 N force. Friction opposes with 20 N to the left. Describe the motion using Newton's First Law.

step_by_step.explanation: Applied force: 20 N right. Friction: 20 N left.
Net force = forces in same direction minus forces in opposite direction. $F_{net} = 20 \text{ N (right)} - 20 \text{ N (left)} = 0$ N
Net force = 0. First Law states: object maintains constant velocity. If box was at rest, it stays at rest. If box was moving at constant velocity, it continues at that constant velocity.
With balanced forces, no acceleration occurs. If starting from rest: remains at rest (zero velocity maintained). If already moving: continues at constant velocity in current direction.

worked_examples.final_answer: Net force = 0 (forces balanced). First Law: constant velocity. If initially at rest, stays at rest. If initially moving, continues at constant velocity. No acceleration.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Balanced forces (net force = 0) produce no acceleration. First Law governs: velocity remains constant (whether zero or non-zero).

image.caption: Inertia: resistance to changes in motion. At rest stays at rest, moving continues moving (unless net force acts)

sections.introduction: Inertia manifests in many everyday situations, explaining phenomena that might otherwise seem mysterious.

categories.description: Objects resist being set in motion from rest.

examples.explanation: Difficult to get couch or refrigerator moving. Once moving, easier to keep it moving (though still need force to overcome friction). Initial difficulty is overcoming inertia—furniture 'wants' to stay at rest.

Takes effort to accelerate from standing still to running speed. Your body resists the change from rest to motion. Once at speed, maintaining constant velocity easier (though friction/air resistance still present).
Massive train has enormous inertia. Requires large force to start moving. Once moving, has significant momentum and takes large force to stop.
Ball continues rolling until friction, your hand, or wall stops it. Ball's inertia maintains motion until net force (friction or impact) acts.
You slide far after stopping your legs because body continues at constant velocity (low friction on ice provides minimal stopping force). Inertia keeps you moving.
Car doesn't stop instantly when brakes applied. Friction force from brakes must overcome car's inertia. Greater mass or higher speed → more inertia to overcome → longer stopping distance.

categories.description: Your body's inertia during vehicle acceleration/deceleration.

examples.explanation: You feel pushed back into seat. Actually, your body's inertia resists forward acceleration—you 'want' to stay at rest (or previous velocity) while car accelerates forward. Seat pushes you forward to accelerate you with car.

You lurch forward. Your body's inertia maintains forward velocity while car decelerates. Seat belt provides force to decelerate you with car. Without seat belt, inertia carries you forward into dashboard/windshield.

You feel pushed outward (toward door). Your inertia maintains straight-line motion while car turns. Door/seat belt provides inward force to make you turn with car. You're not pushed outward—you're pulled inward by door while resisting the turn.

In crash, car stops suddenly. Your body's inertia maintains forward motion at original velocity. Without restraint, you continue forward at high speed into interior or through windshield. Seat belt provides force to decelerate you with car, preventing injury.
Quickly move hands, then stop suddenly. Water's inertia keeps it moving when hands stop, flinging water off. Water 'wants' to continue at constant velocity when hands decelerate.

Yank tablecloth quickly from under dishes. Dishes' inertia resists horizontal motion—they 'want' to stay at rest. Quick pull means cloth slides out before friction has time to accelerate dishes significantly. Dishes stay put (mostly).
Tap bottom of inverted bottle. Bottle accelerates downward briefly, then stops. Ketchup's inertia keeps it moving downward when bottle stops, sliding ketchup out.

image.alt: Illustrations of everyday inertia examples: car braking, shaking water off hands
image.caption: Inertia in daily life: lurching forward when car brakes, water flying off hands when stopped suddenly

sections.introduction: Newton's First Law defines a special class of reference frames called inertial reference frames, where the law holds true.

key_concept.definition: An inertial reference frame is a reference frame in which Newton's First Law holds—objects with no net force have constant velocity. In an inertial frame, there are no 'fictitious forces' (forces that appear due to frame acceleration). Non-inertial frames are accelerating reference frames where First Law appears violated and fictitious forces arise.
key_concept.context: Most physics is done in inertial frames. Earth's surface is approximately inertial (ignoring rotation and orbital motion for typical problems). Accelerating car or rotating carousel are non-inertial—objects appear to accelerate without real forces (you feel pushed backward when car accelerates forward, but no real force pushes you back).

principles.statement: Reference frame where First Law holds. Object with zero net force has constant velocity (including zero). No spontaneous acceleration.
principles.application: Ground, building, slowly moving train at constant velocity are approximately inertial.
principles.example: Ball on floor of train moving at constant 30 m/s: ball at rest relative to train, stays at rest. No net force, no acceleration. First Law works—inertial frame.

principles.statement: Reference frame that is itself accelerating. First Law appears violated—objects accelerate without real forces. Fictitious forces appear (e.g., 'thrown backward' when car accelerates).
principles.application: Accelerating car, rotating platform, elevator starting/stopping are non-inertial.
principles.example: Ball on floor of accelerating train: ball appears to roll backward spontaneously (relative to train) without any force pushing it. Actually, ball maintains constant velocity (inertia) while train accelerates forward—ball's inertia makes it seem to move backward in train's reference frame. Non-inertial frame.

principles.statement: In non-inertial (accelerating) reference frames, objects appear to experience forces that aren't real interactions. These 'fictitious forces' are consequences of frame acceleration.
principles.application: Recognize when you're in non-inertial frame—felt forces may be fictitious.
principles.example: Car accelerating forward: you feel pushed backward into seat. No real force pushes you back. Fictitious force arises because you're in car's non-inertial (accelerating) frame. From ground frame (inertial): seat pushes you forward to accelerate you with car.

worked_examples.title: Inertial vs Non-Inertial Frames
worked_examples.problem: A ball hangs from string attached to ceiling of a train car. (a) Train at rest: describe ball. (b) Train moving at constant 20 m/s: describe ball. (c) Train accelerating forward: describe ball from train's perspective and from ground perspective.

step_by_step.explanation: Ball hangs straight down. Forces: gravity (down), tension (up). Balanced. Net force = 0. Ball at rest. Inertial frame (stationary train).

Ball hangs straight down (same as at rest). Forces still balanced. Net force = 0. Ball at rest relative to train. Constant velocity relative to ground. Inertial frame (constant velocity train—no acceleration).

Ball swings backward (toward rear of train), hangs at angle. Appears like backward force acting on ball. This is fictitious force—train is non-inertial (accelerating) frame. No real backward force exists.

Ball maintains original velocity (inertia) while train accelerates forward under it. String tension pulls ball forward, accelerating it with train, but at angle. String pulls both upward (against gravity) and forward (to accelerate ball). Ball accelerates forward but lags behind ceiling point, appearing to swing back from train's view. Inertial frame (ground)—real forces explain motion, no fictitious forces needed.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a,b) Ball hangs straight down—inertial frames. (c) From train: ball swings back (fictitious force in non-inertial frame). From ground: string pulls at angle to accelerate ball forward (real forces in inertial frame).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Inertial frames: First Law holds, only real forces. Non-inertial frames: fictitious forces appear. Ground is inertial, accelerating train is non-inertial.

image.alt: Diagrams comparing ball in train at rest, constant velocity, and accelerating
image.caption: Inertial frames (rest, constant v): ball hangs straight, First Law holds. Non-inertial frame (accelerating): ball swings, fictitious force appears

sections.introduction: Newton's First Law built on earlier work by Galileo, who first challenged Aristotelian views of motion.

examples.explanation: Force required to maintain motion. Objects naturally come to rest. Heavier objects fall faster. This seemed consistent with everyday observation: push stops → motion stops.
Everyday experience includes friction. We don't encounter frictionless motion naturally. Everything we push stops when we stop pushing—seemed to prove force needed for motion.
Confused force requirement for overcoming friction with force requirement for motion itself. Didn't recognize friction as separate force.

Galileo studied balls rolling down one incline and up another. Ball released from height h on one side reaches nearly height h on other side (slightly less due to friction). Reducing second incline's angle: ball travels farther along incline to reach same height. Logical conclusion: on horizontal surface (zero angle), ball would travel forever (if no friction).
Imagine perfectly smooth surface (no friction). Moving object would continue moving indefinitely without slowing. Motion is natural state as much as rest is.
Objects don't naturally stop—friction stops them. Without friction, motion continues unchanged. Force causes change in motion, not motion itself.

categories.description: Newton refined Galileo's ideas into precise law.

examples.explanation: Newton published his three laws of motion in 1687. First Law formalized Galileo's insight: constant velocity (including zero) is natural state without net force.
Newton provided equations connecting force, mass, and acceleration. Made physics quantitative and predictive.
Overturned 2000 years of Aristotelian physics. Enabled accurate predictions of planetary motion, projectile trajectories, eventually space travel. Foundation of classical mechanics.

summary: Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia) states: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion continues moving with constant velocity (constant speed in straight line), unless acted upon by a net external force. Inertia is the tendency of objects to resist changes in motion—the property that makes objects maintain their current state (rest or constant velocity). Mass measures inertia: greater mass = greater inertia = greater resistance to acceleration. The First Law applies when net force is zero, which occurs when: (1) no forces act, or (2) forces present but balanced (vector sum = 0). Key insight: forces cause changes in motion (acceleration), not motion itself. Constant velocity (including v = 0 as special case) is natural state requiring no net force. Objects slow down in everyday life because friction opposes motion, not because motion naturally ceases. Everyday inertia examples: difficulty starting heavy objects moving, difficulty stopping moving objects, lurching forward when car brakes (body's inertia maintains velocity while car decelerates), feeling pushed backward when car accelerates (body's inertia resists acceleration), seat belts needed because passengers continue at crash velocity when car stops. Inertial reference frames are frames where First Law holds—no spontaneous acceleration, only real forces present (examples: ground, constant-velocity train). Non-inertial frames are accelerating frames where First Law appears violated and fictitious forces arise (examples: accelerating car, rotating platform). Historical development: Aristotle incorrectly believed force required for motion. Galileo's inclined plane experiments and thought experiments revealed objects continue moving without force if no friction. Newton formalized this as First Law in 1687, revolutionizing physics and enabling quantitative predictions. The First Law is foundational: defines inertial frames, explains everyday motion phenomena, introduces inertia concept, prepares for Second Law (quantifying force-acceleration relationship) and Third Law (force interactions).
